The foundations of quantum mechanics are a major open problem in theoretical physics. In this paper, we provide a purely categorical approach to the foundations of quantum mechanics. The axioms are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. This approach is a significant step toward a solution of the foundations problem.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that cause disease in a wide range of animals. The evolutionary origin of this group has been elusive, but a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies. Here, we present the first comparative genomic analysis of two distantly related myxozoan species, which are sister to a cnidarian parasite, and compare these to the genome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This is consistent with the hypothesis that the Myxozoa are a sister group to the Cnidaria. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

COVID-19 is a global pandemic that has caused millions of deaths worldwide. The disease is caused by the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) virus. The virus has a complex life cycle that includes a step in which it hijacks the nuclear import machinery to evade the antiviral action of interferon (IFN). Here, we show that the viral accessory protein Orf6 is responsible for this evasion mechanism. We also show that Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1 to block nuclear import of ISG mRNA. Our data provide a mechanism of viral antagonism that could be used as a target for the development of new antiviral therapies. (Show more)

Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1 channels. However, the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 is not completely understood. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 channel. We propose that Zn2+ binding has two major effects on Hv1: (i) at low concentrations, Zn2+ binds to one site and prevents the opening conformational change of the pore of Hv1, thereby inhibiting proton conduction; and (ii) at high concentrations, Zn2+, in addition, binds to a second site and inhibits the outward movement of the voltage sensor of Hv1. Climate change will affect the productivity of the world’s major crops, including maize. Earlier studies suggest that once the optimum growing temperature is exceeded, mean crop yields decline and the variability of yield increases even if interannual climate variability remains unchanged. Here, we use global datasets of maize production and climate variability combined with future temperature projections to quantify how yield variability will change in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. We find that as the global mean temperature increases, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation (CV) of maize yields increases almost everywhere to values much larger than present-day values. This higher CV is due both to an increase in the standard deviation (SD) of yields and a decrease in mean yields. For the top four maize-exporting countries, which account for 87% of global maize exports, the probability that they have simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year is presently virtually zero, but it increases to 7% under 2 °C warming and 86% under 4 °C warming. The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is critical to understanding the mechanisms of coexistence in natural communities. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level taxa in the field. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammal species in semiarid African savanna. These species ranged from almost-exclusive grazers to almost-exclusive browsers. Grass consumption was highly correlated with isotopic estimates of % grass consumption, indicating that RRA conveys reliable quantitative information about consumption. Dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption. Nonetheless, diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This study highlights the importance of diet composition and composition overlap in determining the extent to which species partition food resources.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on small businesses. We survey more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of the crisis on their operations and finances. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, with many having only a few weeks of cash on hand. Many businesses are planning to apply for the Coronavirus Relief Fund, but many anticipate problems with the application process.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of floating plastic debris is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This discrepancy is likely due to the size-selective removal of floating plastic debris by a combination of processes, including nano-fragmentation, transference to the ocean interior, and sinking processes. This study provides a global perspective on the fate of floating plastic debris and its potential impacts on the marine environment. It also highlights the need for a better understanding of the processes involved in the fate of floating plastic debris. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important questions in astronomy. The solar system is a unique laboratory for studying the early history of the universe. In this study, we determined the ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have ages of <300 Ma and >1 Ga, which is a clear indication that the grains were part of aggregates in the interstellar medium. The grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. This result is important for the understanding of the early history of the solar system. It also provides a unique insight into the formation of the solar system.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. The global fleet is expected to grow further, but at a slower rate, by midcentury. This will challenge sustainable use of fisheries' resources. The expansion of the motorized fleet is driven by the powered-artisanal fleet, which has been growing rapidly. The powered-artisanal fleet is dominated by small vessels, but contributes only 27% of the global engine power. This highlights the importance of small vessels in the global fleet. The powered-artisanal fleet is expected to continue to grow, but at a slower rate, in the coming decades.

The ability to produce offspring is one of the most important traits in nature. In this study, we show that the ability to produce offspring is also one of the most variable traits in nature. We show that the ability to produce offspring is strongly correlated with the amount of energy available to the mother. This suggests that the ability to produce offspring is limited by the mother’s metabolic power rather than resource availability. This is an important finding because it suggests that the ability to produce offspring is a fundamental trait in nature.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. No treatment is currently available to slow down the aggressive neurodegenerative process, and patients die within a few years after disease onset. The cytopathological hallmark of MSA is the accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. Several studies point to α-syn oligomerization and aggregation as a mediator of neurotoxicity in synucleinopathies including MSA. Here, we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the progressive toxicity of α-syn aggregation in a mouse model of MSA. This suggests that VX-765, a drug that was well tolerated in a 6 wk-long phase II trial in patients with epilepsy, is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This study provides an in vivo proof of concept for the potential of VX-765 to treat MSA. The results also suggest that caspase-1 may be a promising therapeutic target in synucleinopathies. This study opens the door to a clinical trial

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are highly specialized to perform these functions. The endothelium is also the first line of defense against pathogens and debris in the blood. The endothelium is composed of thousands of specialized cell clusters that are connected by a network of communication. The communication network is composed of short paths between clusters and high efficiency in the transmission of information. These properties allow the endothelium to rapidly and efficiently control the cardiovascular system. This article provides a detailed description of the communication network and its properties. The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. This paper describes the COVIDcast API, a data source that provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 indicators, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health reporting. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available through an API and accompanying R and Python software packages. The paper provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making. The COVIDcast API is a valuable resource for anyone interested in tracking the pandemic.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion channels in the body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes, including the control of heart rate and blood pressure. The selectivity filter is the narrowest part of the channel and is responsible for the selective permeation of K+ ions. The selectivity filter is structurally coupled to the activation gate, which is responsible for the opening of the channel. We have identified a second Threonine residue within the activation gate as a crucial residue for the functional and structural coupling between the selectivity filter and the activation gate. This residue is responsible for the allosteric communication between the two domains. We have also shown that the selectivity filter can be structurally collapsed by the structural collapse of the activation gate. This structural collapse can be used to achieve closed-state inactivation. This work provides a structural basis for the functional coupling between the selectivity filter and the activation gate. It also provides a structural basis for the design of new potassium channel blockers. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is critical for the health of the host. The role of the gut microbiome in health and disease is just beginning to be understood, and the potential for the microbiome to be manipulated therapeutically is being explored. The gut microbiome is also a dynamic system that is constantly changing in response to the host and the environment. In this study, we investigate the potential of anaerobic fungi to synthesize natural products that could regulate membership within the gut microbiome. This work provides a foundation for the discovery of novel natural products and their potential applications. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior. However, the role of personality in the establishment of social hierarchy remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that predisposes individuals to become subordinate during a social encounter, directly influences social dominance and that this effect is mediated by mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. Our findings highlight the importance of brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The design of multifunctional mechanical devices is highly desired for various applications. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, through a free-form inverse design approach, multiple hyperelastic materials with distinct properties are optimally synthesized into composite structures to precisely achieve arbitrary and extreme prescribed responses under large deformations. The digitally synthesized structures exhibit organic shapes and motions with irregular distributions of material phases. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate through sophisticated deformation mechanisms to produce the target behaviors. While complex in geometry and material heterogeneity, the discovered structures are effectively manufactured via multimaterial fabrication with different polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) elastomers with distinct behaviors and their highly nonlinear responses are physically and accurately realized in experiments. To enhance programmability, the synthesized structures are heteroassembled into architectures that exhibit highly complex yet navigable responses. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. Hemoglobin is the oxygen-carrying protein of red blood cells. The hemoglobin content of red blood cells is determined by the expression of the globin genes. The globin genes are expressed in a developmental context-dependent manner. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is expressed in erythroid tissues and that its expression is developmentally regulated. IGF2BP1 is a potential mediator of the developmental regulation of hemoglobin expression.

Cancer is the leading cause of death worldwide. Despite the development of new therapies, the 5-year survival rate for many cancers remains low. The development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis confers resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis that is regulated by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. This resistance is mediated by the induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. Furthermore, we found that SREBP1 mediates the ferroptosis-suppressing activity of SREBP1 by inducing the expression of stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 (SCD1), a transcriptional target of SREBP1. Finally, we found that the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction shows therapeutic promise in preclinical models. These findings provide a potential mechanism for the development of new therapies for cancer patients. (Read more)

Hypertension is the most common risk factor for heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of cardiovascular disease prevention. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). However, the mechanisms of action of LCCBs are not fully understood. Here, we show that LCCBs activate Ca2+ signaling through STIM/ORAI proteins, which are up-regulated in hypertension. Our findings have implications for the use of LCCBs in patients with advanced hypertension and/or cardiovascular remodeling.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We used >25 years of bird surveys to test whether the NWFP was effective in halting the decline of older-forest–associated birds and stabilizing early-seral–associated birds. We found that the NWFP halted the decline of early-seral–associated birds, but failed to halt the decline of older-forest–associated birds. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. Our findings also highlight the importance of monitoring the effectiveness of policies that affect forests. This study provides a unique opportunity to evaluate the influence of policy.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is therefore a major challenge. Here, we present a rational design approach to identify new acylide antibiotics. The approach is based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. We show that the best candidate is up to 56 times more active than telithromycin, a clinically used antibiotic, against resistant pathogens. The approach is applicable to other antibiotic classes and can be used to screen for new compounds. The approach is also applicable to other antibiotic classes and can be used to screen for new compounds. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often very large, making it difficult to train and apply the networks in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. Our results show that the proposed architecture is a promising candidate for many image-processing problems. This work is expected to be useful for the community in the future.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa (9–15° S). We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. The use of electronic devices for reading and entertainment has become increasingly popular in the past 50 y. However, the biological effects of such devices on sleep and circadian rhythms are unknown. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) suppresses melatonin and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety. These results have implications for the design of future electronic devices and the development of sleep-friendly technologies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Younger Dryas (YDB) cooling is one of the most enigmatic events in the last 10,000 y. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the YDB. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the osmium (Os) isotopic composition of the YDB samples is consistent with terrestrial sources. The rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes of the YDB spherules indicate that their source lies in 1.5-Ga Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America. The Os isotopic composition of the spherules and their leachates is often low, but Os in these objects is likely terrestrially derived. The YDB spherules are the first evidence for an impact event at the YDB. These findings provide a new perspective on the YDB cooling. (Show more)

The role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity is controversial. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice. We found that CTLA-4 deletion induced lymphoproliferation, hypergammaglobulinemia, and organ-specific autoimmunity, accompanied by organ-specific autoantibodies. However, in contrast to congenital deficiency, this was not fatal. CTLA-4 deletion affected both central and peripheral tolerance and Treg cell-mediated suppression. Thus, CTLA-4 deficiency affects both central and peripheral tolerance and Treg cell-mediated suppression. These findings have implications for the treatment of autoimmune diseases. (Read more)

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of this group remains poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of genes encoding microbial enzymes to trace the evolution of beetles, revealing that the origin of beetles coincides with the origin of plant-feeding beetles. These findings suggest that the evolution of beetles was driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding enzymes that digest plant cell walls. These findings have important implications for understanding the evolution of animal diversity and the origin of plant-feeding beetles. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work may help to accelerate the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the paper planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance CCE. In fact, there was an inverse relationship between population size and CCE: plane flight distance did not improve over the experimental generations in the 2-Model and 4-Model conditions, but did improve over generations in the 1-Model social-learning condition. The incremental improvement in plane flight distance in the 1-Model social-learning condition was comparable to that in the Individual Learning condition, highlighting the importance of trial-and-error learning

The apoE gene is the strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) susceptibility. APOE isoform is highly associated with AD risk. APOE2 is associated with decreased AD risk, whereas APOE4 is associated with increased AD risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. APOE2 enhances the rate of phagocytosis of synapses by astrocytes, whereas APO4 decreases it. We also found that APOE4 increases the accumulation of senescent synapses in the brain, which may contribute to AD pathogenesis. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may be associated with increased AD risk due to defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes, which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. This hypothesis is consistent with the observation that APOE4 is associated with increased complement activation in the brain. These studies also suggest that APOE may be a target for AD prevention and treatment. This article is protected by copyright.

The Earth's inner core is a solid sphere with a diameter of 2,890 km, which is the largest solid body in the solar system. The inner core is thought to have formed by crystallization of the liquid core. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still controversial. In this study, we found that the nucleation of the inner core is likely to be two-step, which is different from the crystallization of the liquid. This study provides a new perspective for understanding the formation of the inner core. It also provides a clue for the study of the origin of the solar system's largest solid body. (Show more)

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of chronic marijuana use are well established, the underlying mechanisms are not. Here, we show that the brain’s reactivity to methylphenidate (a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine) is reduced in marijuana abusers, who are more likely to be irritable, anxious, and addicted. These findings suggest that the brain’s reactivity to DA stimulation might contribute to the negative emotionality and addictive behaviors of marijuana abusers. The findings also highlight the need to investigate the effects of chronic marijuana in the human brain.

Language is a uniquely human ability. It is also the most complex behavior we know of. How the human brain processes language is therefore a fundamental question in cognitive neuroscience. Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural networks can do the same for the brain’s neural responses to language that humans do. This suggests that predictive processing, the hallmark of deep learning, is a fundamental mechanism in the brain’s language comprehension mechanism. This also provides a computational framework for understanding the neural correlates of language in the human brain.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major breakthrough in machine learning. However, it is still unclear how stable and accurate it is. In this paper, we show that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks, but there does not exist any algorithm that can train such a network. This is a fundamental difference between deep learning and other machine learning methods. Our results provide a classification theory of stability and accuracy of neural networks.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including the failure of governments to act quickly enough. One of the most frequently cited studies in this context is a classic experiment published 45 years ago. It is often claimed that the study’s design flaws led to its conclusion being “wrong” and that the study should be discarded. Here, we show that the study’s flaws were not only overlooked at the time but, in hindsight, are a unique case study of researchers falling prey to just the cognitive bias they set out to study.

Leprosy is a chronic disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae, which has undergone extensive reductive evolution. In contrast, the pathogen associated with a rare, chronic, noninfectious, and noncommunicable condition known as Lucio's phenomenon, which is characterized by diffuse cutaneous lepromatous leprosy, has not been characterized. Here, we report the genome sequence of M. lepromatosis, which is the causative agent of diffuse lepromatous leprosy. The genomes are similar in size and synteny, and the two leprosy bacilli have retained the ability to cause peripheral neuropathy. However, M. lepromatosis has lost several enzymes required for amino acid synthesis, and M. leprae has a defective heme pathway. These findings suggest that the two leprosy bacilli have diverged in their metabolic capabilities and may have evolved to cause different forms of leprosy. This article is protected by copyright. Entanglement and entropy are the two main resources in quantum information science. They are also the two main ingredients of thermodynamics, the latter being the foundation of statistical mechanics. However, the relation between them is still a matter of debate. In this work, we show that the entanglement dynamics in integrable systems is captured by a quasiparticle picture, which is exact in the scaling limit. This result is a milestone in the study of the relation between entanglement and thermodynamics.

COVID-19 is a highly contagious disease that has resulted in millions of deaths worldwide. The only available vaccines are based on inactivated virus or viral vectors. In contrast, the live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine described here is a promising alternative. The vaccine is easy to manufacture, can be stored at 2–8 °C, and is temperature sensitive, which allows for easy adaptation to mass vaccination programs. The vaccine is also highly protective in a relevant hamster model. These properties make the vaccine a promising candidate for use in mass vaccination programs.

The Black Death, caused by Yersinia pestis, was one of the deadliest epidemics in human history. The disease spread rapidly through Europe, killing millions of people. The vector of the disease is still debated, with arguments for both rats and human fleas. Here, we show that human fleas were the primary vector of the disease during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death. This contradicts the assumption that rats were the primary vector of the disease. Our results have implications for our understanding of the history of plague and the spread of disease in Europe.

The evolution of brain size is a major topic of debate in comparative neurobiology. However, the evolution of brain numbers is rarely considered. Here, we show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition. Our results also suggest that the evolution of brain size and neuronal numbers are decoupled. This has important implications for the evolution of animal intelligence.

The mitochondrial molecular chaperone TRAP1 is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal cells is not well understood. Here, we show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. These data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. This may have implications for the development of TRAP1-targeted therapies. Actin filaments are the main cytoskeletal elements that mediate many cellular processes. They are also the targets of the ADF/cofilin family of proteins, which are critical for the disassembly of the actin cytoskeleton. However, how ADF/cofilin acts on actin filaments in a physiological context, where filaments are interconnected and under mechanical stress, remains unclear. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques to study the action of ADF/cofilin in different mechanical situations. We find that local curvature favors severing, while tension has no effect on cofilin binding and weakly enhances severing. Remarkably, we observe that filament segments that are held between two anchoring points, thereby constraining their twist, experience a mechanical torque upon cofilin binding. We propose that this ADF/cofilin-induced torque increases the severing rate constant 100-fold. A consequence of this mechanism is that cross-linked filament networks are severed far more efficiently than nonconnected filaments. Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in beverages and foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation to food cues and greater hunger and desire for food. These findings suggest that fructose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite than glucose. The findings also suggest that fructose may promote feeding behavior. These results have implications for understanding the mechanisms of obesity and for the development of strategies to reduce the consumption of fructose. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, allowing us to study the history of the settlement of Madagascar. We find that the Malagasy are a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The admixture happened recently, suggesting a rapid settlement of Madagascar during the last millennium. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, there are geographic influences on the present genomic diversity, independent of the admixture, showing that a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. Our results provide insights into the history of Madagascar and the settlement of the Indian Ocean islands. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Emotional contagion is the phenomenon of people experiencing the same emotions as others. It is well established in laboratory experiments, but the evidence from real-world social networks is controversial. Here, we test whether emotional contagion occurs outside of in-person interaction between individuals by reducing the amount of emotional content in the News Feed. When positive expressions were reduced, people produced fewer positive posts and more negative posts; when negative expressions were reduced, the opposite pattern occurred. These results indicate that emotions expressed by others on Facebook influence our own emotions, constituting experimental evidence for massive-scale contagion via social networks. This work also suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. These findings have implications for the design of social media platforms and the design of interventions to promote mental health. (PsycINFO Database Record

Messenger RNA (mRNA) sequences are modified posttranscriptionally to regulate protein synthesis. In this study, we show that the presence of a single pseudouridine (Ψ) in an mRNA codon can impede the addition of amino acids to the growing peptide chain and the activation of the elongation factor EF-Tu. We also find that the presence of Ψ can promote the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence in the bacterial translation system. These findings suggest that the ribosome encounters Ψ in mRNA sequences can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. These findings are important for understanding the function of mRNA modifications and the mechanisms by which the ribosome encounters them. (Read more)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including stronger social relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better health, and a healthier lifestyle. These associations are robust over time and are not explained by factors such as socioeconomic status, depressive symptoms, or prosperity. The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages. These findings have implications for public health and gerontology. (PsycINFO Database Record

The evolution of larger body sizes is a defining characteristic of aquatic mammals. Here, we show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving the evolution of larger body sizes in four of the five extant aquatic mammal lineages. We show that the evolution of larger body sizes is consistent with the energetic constraints of the aquatic environment. These results have implications for the evolution of body size in other aquatic and terrestrial organisms.

The common cold is one of the most common and economically devastating diseases in the world. The cold temperature of the nasal cavity is an important factor in the initiation of the cold virus common cold. However, the mechanism by which the cold temperature of the nasal cavity inhibits the growth of cold viruses is not clear. In this study, we found that the growth of rhinovirus is temperature dependent in primary mouse airway cells. The growth of rhinovirus is inhibited by the antiviral response of airway cells at the cold temperature of the nasal cavity. This study provides a new perspective on the mechanism of the common cold. (Show more)

Bacteria use a variety of mechanisms to sense their environment and respond appropriately. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its pili to sense surfaces and regulate its virulence. This mechanism is similar to the mechanochemical model used by animals to sense the mechanical activity of their muscles. Our findings demonstrate that type IV pili are not only used for twitching motility, but also as a sensor regulating surface-induced gene expression and pathogenicity. This mechanism may be important for the survival of bacteria in the environment.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the last decades. However, the impact of pesticides on the environment is still poorly understood. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global occurrence of pesticides in surface waters. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions. This study is a first step toward a better understanding of the global impact of pesticides on the environment.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human society, and the emergence of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes it, has been a major public health challenge. The virus has been shown to be highly transmissible between humans, but the extent to which it can be transmitted between animals has not been well characterized. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living deer, a finding that has important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic. Our findings highlight the need for a more comprehensive understanding of the ecology and evolution of SARS-CoV-2, as well as the potential for the virus to circulate in animal reservoirs. This will require a One Health approach that involves collaboration between human and animal health experts. Our study provides a starting point for such an effort. (PsycInfo Database Record

The world is moving toward a more sustainable energy future. This paper examines the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable energy sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the lack of effective treatments has led to a global public health crisis. The immune system is increasingly recognized as a critical player in the disease, but the mechanisms by which it contributes are not well understood. Here, we identify the amyloid precursor protein (APP)-expressing neuron as a source of proinflammatory factors that may contribute to the development of AD. This study provides a potential new target for the development of AD therapeutics. It also highlights the importance of considering the intraneuronal accumulation of amyloid as a significant immunological component in the pathogenesis of the disease. The domestic chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation is still unknown. Here we present the results of a faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel. We show that the exploitation of chickens was widespread and economically important in the Hellenistic period. This is the earliest evidence for the economic exploitation of chickens in the world.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a mechanism for regulating gene expression in bacteria. However, the mechanism by which this occurs is not fully understood. Here, we show that the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is inactivated by Np4, is the predominant decapping enzyme in Escherichia coli cells experiencing disulfide stress. We demonstrate that RppH decapsulates Np4-capped RNAs, generating monophosphorylated 5′ termini that are required to stimulate rapid RNA degradation. This work provides insight into the mechanism by which RppH decapsulates Np4-capped RNAs and how this process is regulated during stress. These findings have implications for understanding the role of Np4 in bacterial stress response and for developing new strategies for controlling bacterial infection. (Read more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcome. The mechanisms involved in the immunosuppression that occurs during sepsis are not fully understood. Here, we show that arginine, an essential amino acid, is depleted in sepsis and that this depletion is associated with the expansion of myeloid-derived suppressor cells and regulatory T cells. We also show that increasing arginine availability with citrulline administration is more efficient than arginine administration alone in restoring T cell function and proliferation and decreasing immunosuppression. These results suggest that arginine depletion is a common mechanism in sepsis and that citrulline could be a promising therapeutic strategy to restore immune function and decrease sepsis-induced immunosuppression. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. (Read more)

The biomass of the biosphere is the total amount of organic material on Earth. It is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the kingdoms of life concentrate at different locations on the planet. Finally, we highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. This information is essential for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature and in physics, where a system evolves in time and space, and the rate of change of its state is proportional to the value of the state itself. SOC systems are characterized by the absence of a characteristic time scale and the presence of a power-law distribution of the time scales. In this paper, we report on the discovery of a continuous model of SOC.

Diamond is a promising material for many applications, but its properties are difficult to control. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly by strain engineering. This opens up new possibilities for tailoring its properties.

The discovery of a large number of nodule-specific peptides in the model legume Medicago truncatula has led to the hypothesis that these peptides may have a role in plant defense. However, there is a lack of knowledge regarding their structural architecture, antifungal activity, and modes of action against plant fungal pathogens. Here, we report the structure of one of these peptides, NCR044, and show that it is a potent fungicide against multiple plant fungal pathogens. It binds to multiple bioactive phosphoinositides in vitro and induces reactive oxygen species in germlings of the fungal pathogen Botrytis cinerea. This work provides a structural basis for the antifungal activity of NCR peptides and paves the way for future development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. However, the extent of molecular continuity between the sexes is largely unknown. Here, we show that the Drosophila sperm proteome undergoes substantial compositional changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. Multiple seminal fluid proteins initially associate with sperm, but most become undetectable after sperm are stored. Female-derived proteins also begin to associate with sperm immediately after mating, and they comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome following 4 d of storage in the female reproductive tract. Female-derived proteins that associate with sperm are enriched for processes associated with energy metabolism, suggesting that female contributions support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to the platelet receptor glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) to promote platelet aggregation. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force can switch the conformation of VWF, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism explains the effects of mutations in VWD. The force-switched state is characterized by a faster on-rate and slower off-rate, similar to the behavior of a chemical reaction. This behavior is consistent with the mechanism of a chemical reaction. The force-switched state is also characterized by a large increase in the effects of mutations in VWD. This work provides a mechanism for understanding the effects of mutations in VWD and may be applicable to other proteins that bind to receptors. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The human microbiome is a rich source of information about human health and disease. However, the human virome has been difficult to study, in part because of the lack of a comprehensive database. Here, we present a database of over 45,000 human-associated virus taxa, with over 100 gigabases of viral sequence. We use this database to identify previously unknown associations between viruses and disease. We also show that the human virome is highly diverse, and that the human microbiome is a rich source of viral diversity. This study will help to advance our understanding of the human virome and its role in human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, the ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to investigate the ACI. The HSRL is able to measure the aerosol and cloud properties simultaneously. We demonstrate the capability of the HSRL to investigate the ACI. The results show that the HSRL can provide significant contributions to the ACI investigations. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a subject of debate for more than a century. The temperature of the surface of the early Earth is inferred to have been high, but the temperature of the surface of the modern Earth is much lower. This difference has been difficult to reconcile. Here, we use the thermostability of reconstructed ancestral enzymes to determine the temperature of the surface of the early Earth. Our results suggest that the temperature of the surface of the early Earth was high, consistent with previous interpretations. This study demonstrates the utility of integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data to provide new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Ion channels regulate ion flow by opening and closing their pore gates. K+ channels commonly possess two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We induced C-type inactivation in BK channels and studied the relationship between activation/deactivation and C-type inactivation/recovery. We observed prominent slow C-type inactivation/recovery in BK channels by an extreme low concentration of extracellular K+ together with a Y294E/K/Q/S or Y279F mutation whose equivalent in Shaker channels (T449E/K/D/Q/S or W434F) caused a greatly accelerated rate of C-type inactivation or constitutive C-inactivation. C-type inactivation in most K+ channels occurs upon sustained membrane depolarization or channel opening and then recovers during hyperpolarized membrane potentials or channel closure. However, we found that the BK channel C-type inactivation occurred during hyperpolarized membrane potentials

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with 128 million cases and 409,000 deaths in 2019. The parasite relies on the host cell to facilitate entry into the human body. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the physical properties of the host cell to facilitate entry. This is a major change in our understanding of the invasion process and opens up new avenues for drug development.

Diamond is a promising material for many applications, but its properties are difficult to control. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly by strain engineering. This opens up new possibilities for tailoring its properties.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. However, the impact of humidity on host defense and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that mice housed in low humidity are more susceptible to severe disease following influenza virus infection. We find that low humidity impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of influenza virus infection and disease, and may inform the development of new strategies for influenza vaccine and antiviral therapy. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The brain is thought to build syntactic structures in a hierarchical fashion, with each word in a sentence being merged with the previous word to form a phrase. However, whether and how the brain does so remains unknown. Here, we show that the brain responds to each successive word in a sentence with a sudden increase in high-gamma power, which is consistent with a merge operation. The operation applies equally to words and phrases of arbitrary complexity, and it is consistent with a bottom-up or left-corner parser of the incoming language stream. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This may be a fundamental property of the language system.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in the development of all vertebrates. It is important for the formation of the nervous system, the skeleton, and the immune system. The pathway is also important for the development of cancer. The pathway is regulated by two proteins, Axin and Dishevelled. We show here that the two proteins are regulated differently in different tissues. This may be important for the development of the organism and for the regulation of the pathway in different tissues.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain involved in the regulation of feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. Here we show that this effect is mediated by a circuit involving LH neurons and dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area and dopamine neurons in the substantia nigra. We also show that stimulation-induced eating is blocked by lesions of LH neurons, dopamine neurons in the peri-LH region, or dopamine neurons in the substantia nigra. Finally, we show that this circuit is not involved in the regulation of hunger or satiety. Thus, we present a characterization of brain circuitry that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity. This work may help to elucidate the mechanisms of obesity and lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

Symbiotic associations between plants and nitrogen-fixing bacteria are essential for plant growth and survival, but they are inefficient in delivering nitrogen to the plant. This is a major constraint to the use of biological nitrogen fixation in agriculture. Here, we demonstrate the development of a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen-fixing symbiosis, in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This approach could be used to develop a sustainable nitrogen-fixing agriculture. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest, and its future is critical for the global climate. Despite the importance of the Amazon, the region is undergoing rapid deforestation. Remote-sensed deforestation alerts are widely used to monitor and mitigate deforestation, but the alerts are often too late to deter deforestation. We study a community monitoring program that facilitated transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities in the Peruvian Amazon and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. Our results suggest that the program reduced deforestation, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. The findings imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management. This approach could be replicated elsewhere in the Amazon and elsewhere in the world.

Animals use their ears to listen to the world around them. In this paper, we show that the orb-weaving spider can hear without an ear. The spider’s hearing is outsourced to its web, which acts as an acoustic antenna. The spider can hear by sensing the motion of its web, which is much more sensitive than the spider’s ear. The spider can also adjust and regenerate its web to hear better. This is a unique example of outsourcing and supersizing of hearing in animals.

The climate and health impacts of anthropogenic aerosols and greenhouse gases are difficult to disentangle. We show that the removal of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. Our results indicate that the health benefits of a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are comparable to the benefits of the Kyoto Protocol. The climate and health benefits are greatest in the tropics and subtropics, where the majority of the population lives. Our findings are important for the design of climate and health policies. They also highlight the importance of air pollution in the global climate system. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

COVID-19 is a global pandemic with over 500,000 deaths in the United States alone. The lack of a global vaccine supply has led to the development of a global effort to produce billions of doses of vaccines. Here we report the design of a SARS-CoV-2 RBD protein that is well-suited for large-scale production and elicits a strong immune response. This engineered protein is well-suited for inclusion in a vaccine and can be used to design a virus-like particle. This engineered protein and vaccine design could be used to produce a global vaccine supply. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The role of ALK/Ltk in neural crest development is controversial. Here, we show that zebrafish ALK/Ltk is activated by ALKALs, a family of secreted proteins. We further show that ALKALs are involved in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. Our results provide evidence for a role of ALK/Ltk in neural crest development and suggest a mechanism for the involvement of ALK/Ltk in human diseases. Our findings may also lead to the development of zebrafish models for human ALK/Ltk-related diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The emergence of plague as a human pathogen is one of the most dramatic events in history. The study of ancient plague genomes has revealed the evolutionary steps that led to the emergence of plague as a distinct pathogen. However, the number of ancient genomes available for this study is too small to explore the diversity of the pathogen during its formative years. Here, we present 17 ancient plague genomes from Eurasia dating to 5,000 to 2,500 y BP, which provide a much larger dataset to explore the diversity of the pathogen during this critical period of development. We find that the pathogen was not geographically restricted to a single lineage and spread rapidly across Eurasia. This study provides a more complete picture of the formative years of plague and its early evolution. (Show more)

This work examined the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted support for Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia, but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. The fate of soil organic carbon (SOC) in agricultural systems is a critical issue for the sustainability of global food production. In the United States, the conversion of grassland to cropland has led to the release of massive amounts of SOC to the atmosphere. However, the efficacy of soil health management practices in reducing this loss remains highly uncertain. We show that soil health management practices that incorporate perennial pastures and livestock can sequester SOC and increase the stability of SOC in the soil. These results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to mitigate climate change and support food production. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a more comprehensive approach to identifying and prioritizing the threat of emerging viruses. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spillover and spread to humans. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting ranking of 887 viruses is publicly available and can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This work provides a blueprint for the systematic identification and prioritization of viral threats to human health.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for reproduction. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts pollinators. However, the mechanisms that underlie the production of nectar pigments are poorly understood. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of the plant Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid. We also identify the enzymes responsible for the production of this pigment. These findings provide insight into the evolution of nectar coloration and the mechanisms that underlie the production of nectar pigments.

The genetic history of Europe during the Early Medieval period is poorly understood. This is in part due to the lack of population-level genomic data from this time period. Here we present a genome-wide dataset from 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, dating mostly to the late 5th/early 6th century AD. The analysis of this dataset indicates that women in this population had a very high genetic heterogeneity, including signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, many functional variants were already at modern-like frequencies in this population. These results indicate that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape. The analysis of functional variants also revealed that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. This suggests that positive selection may have played a role in the shaping of the modern European genome. Taken together, our results provide new insights into the genetic history of Europe during the Early Medieval period.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. First, whereas MERS-CoV prefers human DPP4 as its receptor, HKU4 shows the opposite trend. Second, in the absence of exogenous proteases, both MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes mediate pseudovirus entry into bat cells, whereas only MERS-CoV spike, but not HKU4 spike, mediates pseudovirus entry into human cells. The global spread of infectious diseases is a major public health concern. In resource-scarce settings, such as Cambodia, the detection of undifferentiated febrile illness is challenging. We used metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) to investigate the pathogen landscape of undifferentiated febrile illness in a periurban hospital in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including chikungunya virus, Plasmodium knowlesi, and HIV. These findings are important for the early detection of undifferentiated febrile illness, the identification of emerging pathogens, and the deployment of rapid public health response. This study highlights the feasibility of mNGS in resource-scarce settings and the potential of mNGS-based pathogen surveillance to better understand the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens. The human genome is replicated in a discontinuous fashion, with the lagging strand template being synthesized by DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) in a discontinuous fashion. The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is critical to the process of lagging strand replication. In this study, we developed unique kinetic assays to measure the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. We found that the pol δ holoenzyme is relatively stable and maintains a loose association with the PCNA sliding clamp. This behavior has profound implications for the synthesis of Okazaki fragments in humans.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In this work, we demonstrate that RNA can replicate and convert RNA into functional molecules. This represents a major step toward the reconstruction of RNA-based life.

Urban areas are the most populous places on Earth. They are also the most dynamic. They are changing in size, shape, and composition. In this paper, we introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. This work is a step toward a more complete understanding of the physical processes that shape urban areas.

COVID-19 is a highly infectious disease, and the mortality rate is high. The treatment of severe and critical COVID-19 patients is still a challenge. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the interleukin-6 pathway, can improve the clinical outcome of severe and critical COVID-19 patients immediately. Therefore, tocilizumab is a promising treatment for COVID-19.

The role of metal homeostasis in the biology of fungi is well established, but the existence of metal-binding natural products in fungi is less so. Here we report the discovery of a fungal natural product, xanthocillin, that binds copper and has antimicrobial properties. The existence of this type of fungal natural product suggests that the role of metal homeostasis in fungal biology is more widespread than previously appreciated. This work also demonstrates the utility of a biosynthetic cluster in the discovery of a new class of antimicrobial compounds. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The tridymite is cogenetic with the other crystalline minerals, and the amorphous material is a mixture of precipitated silica, diagenesis products, and/or fracture/vein fill. The amorphous material is likely a product of multiple aqueous infiltrations. The amorphous material and the crystalline minerals are all derived from a common source, possibly the crater wall/rim/central peak.
