Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of temperate and boreal forests, but the geographic distribution of this risk and the evolutionary history of trees’ frost resistance are poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost damage risk is strongly associated with the evolutionary history of trees’ frost resistance. Our findings reveal that the risk of frost damage is currently increasing in Europe and Asia, but not in North America, and that this trend is likely to continue in the future. Our results have important implications for land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are critical for the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the developmental origins of these cells are unknown. Here, we show that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by two distinct mechanisms. First, Th17 cells can directly transition to Th1-like cells and, second, Th17 cells can support the development of classic Th1 cells. These results have important implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for inflammatory bowel disease. (Read more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The disease is heterogeneous, with different genetic causes, and the mechanisms of disease progression are not fully understood. Here, we report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS. These cells can be used to study disease mechanisms and to test potential therapies. This method will enable the rapid production of large numbers of cells for disease modeling and drug screening. This will accelerate the development of therapies for ALS. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The gut microbiota of arthropod vectors is critical for pathogen colonization. However, the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the microbiota are poorly understood. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the gut microbiota and facilitates infection. We also show that the protein binds bacterial peptidoglycan, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings provide insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the gut microbiota and facilitate infection in arthropod vectors. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The origin of the avian flight apparatus and the evolution of the short tail are two of the most important evolutionary transitions in the history of birds. Here, we describe a new basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis perplexus, from the Early Cretaceous of China. This discovery increases our understanding of the early evolution of the avian flight apparatus and the mosaic evolution of the avian bauplan.

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the climate system without understanding the role of the atmosphere. In this paper, we show that the atmosphere plays an important role in the climate system.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue. The color of an animal is important for its survival, as it can be used to camouflage the animal in its environment. In this study, we show that the color of some animals can be changed by the presence of a specific protein. This protein is present in many different species, and it is most similar to a protein that is known to inhibit an enzyme that is involved in the digestion of proteins. This discovery is important because it shows that the function of a protein can be changed by the presence of other molecules.

Hypoxia is a common feature of solid tumors, and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the mechanisms by which hypoxia promotes the growth of breast cancer are not well understood. Here, we show that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, which in turn promotes the growth of breast cancer cells in a hypoxic environment. Our findings suggest that targeting ALKBH5 may be a promising strategy for the treatment of breast cancer. This study also provides a mechanism for the regulation of m6A modification in response to hypoxia. (Read more)

The earliest pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century. The source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. The Latin term abortivum in many sources has led some scholars to suggest that fetal calves or sheep skins were used. Others have argued that it would not be possible to sustain herds if so many pocket Bibles were made from fetal skins. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The noninvasive method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction in the last 542 My. The age model for this event is critical for understanding the causes and mechanisms of extinction and recovery. We present a precise age model for the Permian-Triassic boundary based on U-Pb dates from five volcanic ash beds. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle precedes the extinction and is punctuated by a sharp negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. The carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. Decamillenial to millennial level resolution of the mass extinction and its aftermath will permit a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion. This age model will also be critical for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that plays important roles in various biological processes, including circadian rhythm, cancer, and metabolism. However, the function of RORα in the intestinal epithelium is still unclear. Here, we generated intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific RORα-deficient mice and found that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORαΔIEC mice exhibit excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Transcriptome analysis reveals that deletion of RORα leads to up-regulation of NF-κB target genes in IECs. Chromatin immunoprecipitation analysis reveals corecruitment of RORα and histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3) on NF-κB target promoters and subsequent dismissal of CREB binding protein (CBP) and bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) for transcriptional repression. The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the immune system and for neutralizing antibodies. We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in complex with the human receptor, angiotensin-converting enzyme 2, and the human ACE2-binding site in the spike is conserved. We also show that the D614G mutation in the spike has resulted in a more open conformation that may facilitate binding to the receptor. These results provide insight into the mechanism of the D614G mutation and may help to inform the development of future vaccines and therapeutics. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. Our results are new even in the case of finite games.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. Black and Latino Americans have experienced a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality, reflecting persistent structural inequalities that increase risk of exposure to COVID-19 and mortality risk for those infected. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our medium estimate indicates a reduction in US life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y to 77.48 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. The chemical properties of atoms are fundamental to chemistry, and they are the basis of the periodic table. The chemical properties of elements are also the basis of the chemical reactions that take place in the universe. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms change with pressure, and that these changes are consistent with the periodic table. This work has implications for the understanding of the universe and the origin of life.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and intensity of extreme fire events. However, the role of human ignitions and fire suppression in driving fire regimes is poorly understood. Here, we show that human ignitions can reduce the risk of extreme fire events, but that this is not always the case. We find that climate change is likely to reduce the risk of extreme fire events, but that this is not always the case. Our results highlight the importance of human ignitions and fire suppression in driving fire regimes and the potential for climate change to reduce this risk. This has implications for the future trajectory of global warming.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms by which this occurs are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its luminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, in a diel rhythm. This glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which is thus able to maintain a stable population level only during the night. This work provides a new perspective on the regulation of symbiosis dynamics and opens the door to the study of other nutrients that may be regulated in this way. (Show more)

Text data are ubiquitous and have been used to study a wide range of topics. However, the latent patterns in text data are often difficult to identify. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. Our method is based on advances in machine learning and can be applied to a variety of domains. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. The disease was transmitted by the flea, which feeds on the blood of infected rodents. The rodent reservoirs of the second plague pandemic are still unknown. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. This study provides a new perspective on the history of the plague pandemic and its impact on human societies. It also offers a new approach to the study of the history of infectious diseases. Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and are important for the functioning of coastal ecosystems. However, they are also a valuable food resource for a variety of predators, including humans. In the Northeast Pacific, asteroids are currently experiencing a mass mortality event, which is associated with a densovirus. This is the first report of a virus associated with this event.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common type of blood cancer, and the prognosis is poor. The identification of targets for therapy is therefore of great importance. Here, we show that a monoclonal antibody targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is effective in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects, and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Furthermore, we show that an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling can suppress the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Thus, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This approach may be applicable to other types of cancer. (Read more)

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, revealing a Bantu and Austronesian ancestry for all Malagasy individuals. We also found a limited contribution of Europeans and Middle Easterners to the Malagasy population. The recent origin of the Malagasy population is supported by the distribution of African and Asian ancestry, which suggests that the settlement of Madagascar happened independently from Africa and Asia. Finally, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar. It also provides a framework to study the history of other island populations. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC) that interacts with aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (denoted GlpD) and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. Consistent with this observation, we found that the RNA base pairs with the cadA and galE promoters and that translation interferes with the observed repression of cadA and galE by the RNA. These results demonstrate that the translation and base-pairing functions compete. This is an example of a dual-function RNA that encodes a protein and base pairs with promoters. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of next-generation antibody-based therapeutics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Crop experts are the primary source of information on the status of crops in the field. However, their assessments are subjective and qualitative, and are not easily amenable to quantitative analysis. We propose a method to convert the original crop expert assessments into a continuous probabilistic variable, which can be used to monitor crop status and predict yields. We show that this index can be used to provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results demonstrate the potential of leveraging the network of “people as sensors” to improve agricultural monitoring and management. This approach can be extended to other crops and countries, and can be used to monitor the status of other natural resources.

Language is a complex system that relies on the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind information over time. This is a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community and the general public. However, the response of soil respiration to warming remains unclear, with some studies showing an increase in soil respiration with warming and others showing no change. Here, we present the largest global synthesis of soil respiration measurements to date, spanning nine biomes and 27 temperature manipulation studies. Our analysis provides limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Moreover, across all biomes, respiration rates with and without experimental warming follow a Gaussian response, increasing with soil temperature up to a threshold of ∼25 °C, above which respiration rates decrease with further increases in temperature. This consistent decrease in temperature sensitivity at higher temperatures demonstrates that rising global temperatures may result in regionally variable responses in soil respiration, with colder climates being considerably more responsive to increased ambient temperatures compared with warmer regions. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. The origin of plastids and their early evolution are still debated. The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is a key event in the evolution of life on Earth. Here, we show that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle, characterized by the dependence of the parasite on the host to fulfill its life cycle, is the main driver of the evolutionary changes in plastid genomes. We propose a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle. Our findings suggest that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. This evolutionary process may have contributed to the origin of plastids and their early evolution. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the risks of climate change. However, the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the drought risk in South Africa is still uncertain. Here, we use a high-resolution climate model to estimate the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in the region. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This work is important for informing climate change adaptation strategies in the region. The discovery of quasicrystals in nature and in the laboratory has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. The first known quasicrystal, found in the Khatyrka meteorite, was discovered in 1976. Since then, the number of known quasicrystal-forming elements has grown to 100. The discovery of the oldest known anthropogenic quasicrystal, in red trinitite, the first nuclear test explosion, is a significant milestone in the history of quasicrystals.

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the biosynthesis of chlorophyll, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated cyclase enzymes using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use BchE, an O2-sensitive [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess an O2-dependent enzyme, the major catalytic component of which is a diiron protein, AcsF. Plant and cyanobacterial mutants in ycf54 display impaired function of the O2-dependent enzyme, accumulating the reaction substrate. Swapping cyclases between cyanobacteria and purple phototrophic bacteria reveals three classes of the O2-dependent enzyme. These data delineate three classes of O2-dependent cyclase in chlorophototrophic organisms from higher plants to bacteria, and their evolution is discussed herein. (Show more)

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in many neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (MAP3K) ASK1. In this study, we found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in generating and maintaining disease, and ASK1 deficiency in microglia/macrophages reduced disease severity. We also found that ASK1 in astrocytes plays a proinflammatory role in the later stage of EAE, suggesting a greater proinflammatory role of astrocytes in the later stage. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages and astrocytes are promising therapeutic targets for reducing neuroinflammation. These findings also suggest that ASK1 may be a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation in MS. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of ASK1 in the pathogenesis of EAE and suggests a potential therapeutic strategy for the treatment of neuroinflammation. California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. The drought began in 2012 and has led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We find that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is attributable to human activities. The probability of drought has increased because of the occurrence of warm conditions when precipitation deficits are more likely to produce drought. This finding has important implications for the future of California and other regions that are experiencing or are likely to experience increasing drought.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a broad phenotypic spectrum. The etiology of autism is so complicated because it involves the effects of variants of several hundred risk genes along with the contribution of environmental factors. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. Here, we show that the loss of function of five autism-risk gene homologs in Drosophila leads to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the autism-risk genes and their functions and may facilitate the development of new approaches for autism diagnosis and treatment. The news media are under intense scrutiny for their role in shaping public opinion. This work reports on a 17-country, 6-continent experiment that examines the extent to which people around the world react more strongly to negative than positive news content. Results show that this is indeed the case, and that the magnitude of this negativity bias varies considerably across individuals. This variation in responsiveness may help explain the prevalence of negative news content around the world. The results also suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

Stormorken syndrome is a rare, multisystem disorder characterized by thrombocytopenia, bleeding diathesis, miosis, and tubular myopathy. Here, we report that mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein STIM1 and ORAI1 cause Stormorken syndrome. We show that p.R304W in STIM1 causes spontaneous bleeding and that p.P245L in ORAI1 suppresses the slow inactivation of the CRAC channel. These findings expand our understanding of the molecular function of the CRAC channel and suggest new therapies for patients with Stormorken syndrome and related conditions. The spread of protein aggregates in the brain is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are poorly understood. Here we use a model of Huntington’s disease to show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain. These aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons. We show that the release of aggregates requires active fusion of the cell membrane, demonstrating that the release of aggregates is an active process. These results provide insight into the mechanisms underlying the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Bats are increasingly accepted as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks through spillover to other animals and humans. However, our understanding of the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats is very limited. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of LTA4H in the immune response of bats and the potential for LTA4H as a target for antiviral therapy. These findings may help to elucidate the mechanisms of viral spillover from bats and provide a basis for the development of new antiviral strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

One of the key metabolic pathways that supports cell growth is the one-carbon unit biosynthetic pathway, which is supported by the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). Here we report the discovery of a series of small-molecule inhibitors of SHMT. We show that these compounds are effective in vitro and in vivo, and that they are particularly effective in cancer cells. We also show that one-carbon metabolism is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by mutations in multiple genes, and the pathological hallmark of the disease is the presence of inclusions in the brain and spinal cord. These inclusions are composed of mutant proteins, which are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these proteins. Instead, the inclusions contain proteins that are supersaturated in the cell, but not when the average of all human tissues is considered. This suggests that the inclusions are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a new perspective on the pathogenesis of ALS and suggests a potential therapeutic target. (PsycInfo Database Record

Cold atoms are a versatile platform for exploring fundamental physics and for applications in quantum technologies. However, the ability to control the interactions between atoms is limited. Here, we present a 2D photonic crystal device that can be used to control the interactions between cold atoms. The device is based on a 2D photonic crystal, which is a type of photonic crystal that can be fabricated in a 2D material. The device can be used to control the interactions between atoms, including the ability to control the direction of the emitted light, the spontaneous decay of the atoms, and the ability to control the interactions between atoms. This device can be used to explore new physics and applications in many-body physics and quantum technologies.

The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The earliest flowering plants are poorly known, and the origin of aquatic flowering plants is still a matter of debate. The study of Montsechia, a plant from the Cretaceous, opens the possibility that aquatic habitats may have played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages.

The evolution of viruses is a key topic in the field of virology. However, the evolutionary history of viruses is difficult to study, as they are typically very small and their genomes are difficult to sequence. Here, we present the first ancient viral genomes, which are from ∼70-y-old human remains. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is ∼12.6 kya, and that the recombination event that formed the current B19V genotype 2 occurred ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. It also shows that ancient viral sequences can be used to study the evolution of viruses in the distant past. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Sea level is rising, and it is rising quickly. This is well known, but the rate of rise is a matter of some debate. This study provides a new estimate of the rate of rise, based on a 25-y time series of satellite altimeter data. The rate of rise is 0.084 ± 0.025 mm/y2, which, when coupled with the average rate of climate-change–driven sea level rise over the same period, implies a sea-level rise of 65 ± 12 cm by 2100. This estimate is in good agreement with the IPCC AR5 model projections. This study provides an important contribution to the ongoing debate about the rate of sea level rise.

Pain is a major public health problem, but the reasons for the rise in pain are not well understood. We show that pain is higher today for those in midlife than for today’s elderly. This is not the expected pattern, and it is not explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity. Instead, it is consistent with the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. Here, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed picture of the structure and reactivity of a key enzyme intermediate. This work highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme reactions. The study also demonstrates the utility of NMR-assisted crystallography in the study of nonnative protein–ligand complexes. This work is expected to be of interest to the structural biology community, as well as to enzymologists and biochemists. (Read more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe and often fatal disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the high case fatality rate of the disease stresses the need for the availability of effective antiviral treatments. Here, we show that remdesivir, an investigational broad-spectrum antiviral, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. However, the mechanisms by which this occurs are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its luminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, in a diel rhythm. This glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which is required for the maintenance of a healthy symbiosis. This glycan is provided only at night, when the squid is active and the symbiotic organ is colonized by immune cells. We propose that this strategy may be used by other hosts to regulate the activities of their associated microbes. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Suspension rates in US schools have risen sharply in recent decades. This study shows that a scalable, evidence-based intervention can reduce suspension rates by half. The intervention is simple: teachers are encouraged to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline. This intervention is scalable because it can be implemented by teachers themselves, with minimal training. It is evidence-based because it is based on a large-scale field experiment. This study has implications for the future of US schools.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to transcriptional mutagenesis. However, the molecular mechanisms of transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated the transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. We found that the transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three alkylated DNA lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove alkylated DNA template. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route stemming from GMP misincorporation was observed for the major-groove alkylated DNA template. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. Taken together, this work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. To infect human cells, MERS-CoV must first bind to cell receptors and then fuse with the cell membrane. The spike (S) glycoproteins are cleaved sequentially during these processes, but the mechanisms by which these cleavages contribute to infection are unknown. Here, we show that the first cleavages are required for MERS-CoV to infect human lung-derived cells, but not other cell types. These findings suggest that the first cleavages are significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. Furthermore, the requirement for the first cleavages may be relevant to other viruses that require sequential proteolysis for infection. Thus, the first cleavages may be important targets for antiviral therapy. (Read more)

The food system is a major contributor to global environmental change and a leading cause of biodiversity loss. The food system also contributes to population health, but the food choices people make are influenced by a complex set of factors. Here, we show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a large-scale catering operation can increase the proportion of vegetarian meals purchased by 14 percentage points. This is equivalent to a proportional increase of 61% in the proportion of vegetarian meals purchased. This is a large effect and has the potential to make a significant contribution to the global sustainability of the food system. The results also suggest that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering operations is a scalable and cost-effective way to promote population health. This approach could be used to help achieve the goals of the UN Sustainable Development Goals.

The cell surface is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. It is a dynamic and complex environment, and the surfaceome is the collection of all the proteins that are exposed to the extracellular space. Here we use a combination of quantitative proteomics and glycoproteomics to show how the surfaceome is remodeled in a collection of six different oncogenes, including EGFR, HER2, KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our findings suggest that vote-by-mail is a policy that can be implemented with minimal costs and that it is unlikely to affect the outcome of elections.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has resulted in millions of deaths worldwide. The mechanisms by which the virus causes disease and spreads rapidly are not fully understood. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2. This interface is likely to be important for immune evasion and spread of the virus. These findings provide insight into the mechanisms of the virus and may lead to the development of new therapeutics. (Read more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying this process are not fully understood. Here we show that hypoxia triggers cortical release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), which acts on CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1) to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms of cerebral edema induced by hypoxia and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The world is full of associations. We are interested in the ones that are important. But how do we decide which are important? This is the problem of selective inference. We describe some recent developments in this area and illustrate their use in a variety of contexts.

The development of vascular ECs is a critical step for the formation of functional vascular networks. However, the direct conversion of nonvascular cells into ECs has not been achieved. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) can directly convert primary human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular ECs (ETVECs). ETV2 is essential for the development of ETVECs, and ETV2 is sufficient to induce the development of ETVECs in vitro and in vivo. These findings provide a promising approach for the generation of ECs for the treatment of vascular disorders and the regeneration of vascular networks. This study also provides a potential strategy for the generation of ECs for the treatment of vascular disorders and the regeneration of vascular networks. (Show more)

The orphan receptor tyrosine kinases anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) are important drivers of cancer. Here, we show that the augmentor ligands of Alk and Ltk are essential for zebrafish pigmentation. These ligands are required for the development of iridophores, a specialized class of photoreceptor cells that are responsible for the production of color in the adult zebrafish. Our results establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. These findings provide insights into the function of Alk and Ltk in vivo and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. In this study, we found that STING is required for normal β-cell function and insulin secretion. STING deficiency in β-cells caused glucose intolerance due to impaired insulin secretion. Moreover, STING deficiency in peripheral tissues caused insulin resistance and glucose intolerance. These findings suggest that STING is a potential target for the treatment of T2D. This study also provides a new perspective for the study of the pathogenesis of T2D. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza epidemics and occasional pandemics. Their genome is segmented into eight RNA fragments, which offers evolutionary advantages but complicates genomic packaging. The existence of a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion, is suspected, but its molecular details remain unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction takes place in infected cells and is required for optimal viral replication. Disruption of this interaction decreased the amount of viral RNA in the viral particles, resulting in an eightfold increase in empty viral particles. This interaction is not widely conserved among influenza A viruses. The lack of conservation might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. Our findings provide insights into the molecular mechanisms of viral packaging and might contribute to the development of new influenza vaccines. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is the leading cause of death worldwide. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a complex process that involves multiple cellular and molecular events. The focal nature of atherosclerotic lesions suggests an important role of local hemodynamic environment. In this study, we found that the activation of YAP/TAZ by disturbed flow is critical for the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesion formation. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerotic lesions and suggest a potential therapeutic target for the prevention and treatment of atherosclerosis. (Show more)

Wildfire is a natural process that has shaped the landscape of the United States for millennia. However, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen dramatically in recent decades. Climate change has likely contributed to the increase in wildfire activity, but the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Human-caused wildfires disproportionally occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-started fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Urban areas are the primary setting for human activity and interaction. As such, they are also the primary setting for the spread of ideas, diseases, and other phenomena. In this paper, we introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to show that the physical appearances of neighborhoods matter for their economic and demographic outcomes. Specifically, we find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. We also find that neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. This work also provides a proof of concept for a new approach to urban studies.

Natural repellents are a promising alternative to synthetic pesticides. However, their molecular targets in arthropod pests remain elusive. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that mediates the perception of natural repellents. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropod pests, and also sheds light on the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the within-host dynamics of ZIKV infection are likely important. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV infection in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the rate of viral production is rapid and the eclipse phase is likely short. We also show that an antiviral treatment that blocks viral replication can be effective if given prophylactically starting at the time of infection. Finally, we show that a drug that inhibits viral replication can be effective if given early after infection. These results can help guide the development of effective therapies for ZIKV infection. (Show more)

Coral bleaching is a widespread phenomenon that is considered a key indicator of the health of coral reefs. However, the mechanisms underlying the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis are still poorly understood. Here, we show that the metabolic state of the coral host is a key factor in the breakdown of the symbiosis. We demonstrate that the catabolism of amino acids during heat stress promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. This leads to an energy limitation of the coral host, which in turn promotes the degradation of the symbiosis. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the stability of the coral holobiont and may help us to predict the fate of coral reefs in a changing climate. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The intestinal epithelium is a complex tissue that forms a barrier to the environment and regulates the absorption of nutrients, the mounting of immune responses, and the prevention of systemic infections. In this study, we investigate the consequences of tumorigenesis on the microbiome using a Drosophila intestinal tumor model. We show that upon loss of BMP signaling, tumors lead to aberrant activation of JNK/Mmp2 signaling, followed by intestinal barrier dysfunction and commensal imbalance. In turn, the dysbiotic microbiome triggers a regenerative response and stimulates tumor growth. Our experiments identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our findings may help to understand the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis and the development of new therapeutic strategies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. The treatment of breast cancer with chemotherapy may lead to the emergence of cancer stem cells or tumor-initiating cells, which have an enhanced capacity for self-renewal, tumor initiation, and/or metastasis. Here we show that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also show that targeting ROR1 with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab can repress the expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduce activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impair the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize or reengraft mice. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Read more)

The start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is often ascribed to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies, but this is difficult to reconcile with the timing of the onset of stratospheric ozone depletion. Here, we show that the start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation was preceded by a series of massive volcanic eruptions, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and climate changes that plausibly linked the eruptions to the onset of accelerated deglaciation. This study provides a unique example of how volcanic eruptions can be used to link climate change to specific events in the past. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Freshwater fisheries are an important source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, they are often overlooked in global assessments of the state of the world’s fisheries. Here, we provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of the world’s catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also find that inland fisheries are a critical source of animal protein for the poor and undernourished. However, the high dependence of poor people on freshwater fisheries in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors underscores the need for improved management. Our data can be used to inform environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2 delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2

The ability to regenerate after injury is a fundamental property of the nervous system that is lost in the adult mammalian CNS. In this study, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, a major regulator of regeneration in the adult CNS. This discovery opens up a new platform for the discovery of factors that regulate regeneration in the adult nervous system.

The process of recombination is fundamental to the functioning of the genome. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus. We find that recombination rates vary widely across the genome, with some regions experiencing no recombination at all. These regions are interspersed with regions of intense recombination, which we call hotspots. The hotspots are more likely to terminate in exons than in introns, and they tend to occur near the start of genes. These results are consistent with the idea that hotspots are a conserved feature of eukaryotic genomes. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The resting brain is a complex system, with a large number of functionally interacting networks. The identification of these networks is a major challenge in the field. Here, we used a novel approach to identify and validate reproducible resting state networks in healthy and disease populations. We found that the dominant resting metabolic network in healthy subjects was topographically similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease, this dominant network was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired at rest and during task performance. We found that the dominant resting metabolic network was deactivated during task performance, and this abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. In contrast, in Alzheimer’s disease, the dominant resting metabolic network was already present at diagnosis, progressing over time. These results provide a direct link between resting metabolic networks and brain function. They also provide a framework for the development of new imaging techniques that can be used to study the resting brain in health and disease.

RNA modifications are important for the function of many RNAs in the cell. In bacteria, the best studied modification is the 5′ nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) modification of transfer RNAs. In this study, we identify a 5′ NAD+ cap in yeast. This cap is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. The 5′ NAD+ cap is not found on pre-mRNAs, suggesting that it is produced cotranscriptionally. The 5′ NAD+ cap may be important for the function of these mRNAs. This study also demonstrates that the 5′ cap structure is not the only RNA modification site in yeast.

The study of the epigenetic mechanisms of diabetes complications has been hampered by the lack of a cohort study with a long-term follow-up. Here we show that DNA methylation patterns at specific loci in blood cells are different in people with diabetes compared with controls, and that these differences persist over time. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory, the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in the long-term follow-up. Our findings may also have implications for the development of new therapeutic strategies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. The role of the fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) in TNBC has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 is highly expressed in TNBC and is associated with poor prognosis. FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease with high morbidity and mortality. The mechanisms of the disease are not fully understood, but it is generally accepted that it is a brain disorder. In this study, we show that some alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving. Moreover, we found that the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol-dependent subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of alcohol dependence and that it may be a previously unidentified target in the management of this disease. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals that contribute to the overall aroma. These compounds are produced during ripening, and the biosynthetic pathways are not known. Here, we report the discovery of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations of precursors to produce the volatiles. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato flavor and lays the foundation for the development of improved cultivars. (Read more)

The loss of biodiversity and the warming of the planet are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of the Earth’s ecosystems. However, these two threats are frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects. Here we show that the loss of biodiversity and the warming of the planet can have opposing effects on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As biodiversity declines, the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning becomes steeper, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning. This key result was driven by two processes linked to variability in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. Our findings have important implications for the design of biodiversity conservation and climate change mitigation strategies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for the formation of spatial maps. However, the organization of its neurons is still debated. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely behaving mice. We found that grid cells, which are critical for the formation of grid representations, are anatomically distinct from other neurons. This study provides a powerful tool for future studies of the organization of MEC neurons. It also provides a model for the study of the organization of the brain in general. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a variety of factors. In this study, we show that the FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) gene is not required for flowering of the host plant, but is required for flowering of the parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the Cuscuta australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also provides a new perspective on the role of FTs in flowering regulation. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The dopamine system of the brain powerfully influences movement and motivation. Here, we describe a unique type of neuronal formation that is composed of striosomes, dopamine-containing dendrites, and their parent cell bodies in the substantia nigra. These formations, which we term “striosome–dendron bouquets,” are likely critical to the integrative functions of the dopamine system. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. This work provides a model for the study of the organization of the dopamine system in the brain. It also has implications for the study of other systems in the brain that are composed of specialized formations of neurons. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We are social creatures, and we seek connection. But how do we know when we are connected? We asked people to talk with each other and rated their felt connection. We found that the speed at which people responded to each other predicted their felt connection. Within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Finally, we demonstrate that this signal is used by third-party listeners as a heuristic of how well people are connected. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for generating the heart rate. The SAN is also the site of the heart’s natural rhythm. In this study, we found that the store-operated Ca2+ entry channel STIM1 is expressed in the specialized cardiomyocytes of the SAN. We also found that STIM1 regulates the heart rate by controlling the content of the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) of the cardiomyocytes. This study reveals a mechanism by which the SR content of the cardiomyocytes is linked to the electrical activity of the SAN. This mechanism may be important for the normal function of the SAN. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, its function in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well characterized. Here, we show that Si pretreatment enhances resistance against the rice leaffolder in rice plants, and that this effect is associated with an increase in jasmonate (JA) accumulation and defense gene expression. These results suggest that Si and JA interact to promote plant defense against insect herbivores. This study provides insights into the role of Si in plant defense and may lead to the development of Si-based strategies for insect pest management. (Read more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the activation of macrophages. Our results suggest that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of macrophage activation.

Language is a complex system that relies on the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is suitable for the binding of linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Plants are sessile organisms and are unable to move to avoid toxic stimuli. Thus, they are dependent on their environment for survival. In order to survive, plants must be able to sense their environment and respond accordingly. In order to respond, plants must be able to deliver molecules to the site of action. Here, we show that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver molecules across the cell wall of plants. This work establishes the feasibility of using DNA nanostructures for biomolecule delivery to plants and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization. This work also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is a significant step toward the development of DNA nanostructures as a tool for plant biology.

The world’s largest lakes are vulnerable to coastal eutrophication, which can alter the structure and function of nearshore ecosystems. However, the role of small tributaries in delivering nutrients to lakes is poorly understood. We show that small tributaries can be a significant source of coastal nutrients, especially in lakes with large catchment areas. Our findings suggest that small tributaries may be a significant source of coastal nutrients in large lakes, and that nutrient management efforts should consider the role of small watersheds in coastal eutrophication. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The study of chemical reactions in the presence of external forcing is of fundamental interest in chemistry and biology. Here, we study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamically forcing environment. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of the external forcing. Our results suggest that the extremization of external forcing may be a general principle that governs the dynamics of complex systems.

The mechanisms by which antibodies against the N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptor disrupt neuronal function and cause autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Ab encephalitis causes changes in the spectral composition of spontaneous electroencephalogram (EEG) activity, which are predicted by a dynamic model of the cortical microcircuit. We also show that these changes are reversible when the model parameters are changed. These findings offer mechanistic insights into the circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Ab. They also suggest that the EEG may be a useful biomarker for the diagnosis and monitoring of NMDAR-Ab encephalitis. This work may also have implications for the development of new therapies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The history of abrupt climate change is a key area of research in Earth system science. However, the history of abrupt climate change is poorly understood because of the difficulty in identifying and quantifying these events. Here, we present a case study of an abrupt climate change event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that this event was associated with a doubling of atmospheric CO2 and a biodiversity nadir. We also show that this event was linked to an increase in organic matter burial and anoxia. These results have implications for our understanding of the history of abrupt climate change and the potential for future abrupt climate change. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. Despite its popularity, the impact of RSPO certification on tropical deforestation remains unclear. Here, we show that RSPO certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results suggest that certification is not a silver bullet for tropical deforestation. Rather, it is one tool among many that must be used in combination to achieve the goal of zero net deforestation.

The exocytosis process is essential for the transport of molecules from the endoplasmic reticulum to the plasma membrane and the recycling of endosomes. The exocyst complex is involved in the last steps of these processes. In this study, we discovered a small molecule that inhibits the exocytosis process. This study provides a valuable tool for studying the regulation of the exocytosis process and a potential target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in the evolution of animals. In many species, sex is determined by a single genetic locus, resulting in two sexes. In species with multiple sex determination alleles, however, sex determination is polygenic, resulting in more than two sexes. Here we show that the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii has four possible sex classes, with two sexes (female and male) and two genotypes (ZZ and XY). We show that the modularity of secondary sexual characteristics produced by polygenic sex determination provides context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. Our results suggest that the maintenance of sex determination alleles is not a simple matter of genetic fitness, but rather a complex interplay of genetic, developmental, and environmental factors. This work provides a framework for understanding the evolution of sex determination in vertebrates.

The retina is a highly oxidative tissue that relies on Fe for redox active energy and electron transfer. We sought to understand how Fe levels impact the retina, given that retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cells are also challenged by accumulations of vitamin A aldehyde adducts (bisretinoids) that photogenerate reactive oxygen species and photodecompose into damaging aldehyde- and dicarbonyl-bearing species. In this study, we show that Fe levels in the retina are critical for the redox stability of bisretinoids and their photodegradation products. These findings have implications for the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly, and other retinal diseases. (Read more)

Predators are the foundation of all food webs, and the evolution of new prey-types is a key process in the diversification of predator communities. However, the evolution of new prey-types is often considered a dead end, due to the constraints associated with morphological and functional optimizations throughout the organism. Here we show that siphonophores, a group of pelagic predators, can evolve new prey-types via modular evolution of their specialized prey-capture structures. Our findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs. They also help build a broader perspective on predatory niche diversification via morphological innovation and evolution. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The evolution of the human hand is one of the most important and enigmatic aspects of human evolution. The earliest hominin hands are incomplete, and the earliest evidence for the evolution of the modern human hand is controversial. Here we report the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. This fossil provides the earliest evidence for the evolution of a key derived characteristic of the human hand and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This finding has important implications for the evolution of the human hand and the origins of modern human behavior. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth. One of the key metabolic pathways that supports cell growth is the one-carbon unit biosynthetic pathway, which is supported by the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). Here we report the discovery of a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT, which blocks tumor growth in mice. We also report that one-carbon unit deficiency is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, a cancer type that is notoriously difficult to treat. These findings provide a foundation for the development of SHMT inhibitors as a cancer therapy. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The world is facing a triple crisis of food, nutrition, and environmental security. This study shows that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, and that this impact is exacerbated when forests are fragmented. The results have important implications for policy makers, who should consider the role of forests in meeting nutrition goals, and for researchers, who should consider the impact of deforestation on people’s diets. This study also highlights the need for more research on the role of natural landscapes in meeting nutrition goals.

Modern farm machinery has greatly increased agricultural productivity, but at the cost of higher vehicle weights that have led to compaction of the soil. Compacted soil is less able to support plant roots, and the compaction depth has increased over time. We show that the total weight of modern farm machinery is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods. This suggests that the effects of modern mechanization on soil compaction are comparable to those of prehistoric sauropods. We hypothesize that the ecological strategies of sauropods, including roaming, would have reduced the negative effects of compaction on soil productivity. Our results highlight the need for more stringent design of farm machinery to reduce subsoil compaction. This is of particular importance in light of the increasing mechanization of agriculture.
